etymologies: mid 17th century (in an earlier sense). From post-classical Latin oppodeltoch, probably coined by Paracelsus; perhaps from ancient Greek ὀπός vegetable juice; for the ending, perhaps compare post-classical Latin nostoch

definitions: An alcoholic solution of soap (or oleic acid) and camphor with some added essential oils; soap liniment; (also) a preparation made from this, especially by mixing with laudanum; now archaic. In extended use: (United States regional) any medicine; alcohol.

notes.text: "Steer's opodeldoc" noun a soap liniment composed of soap, camphor, oils of marjoram and rosemary, alcohol, and ammonia solution.
